Bimetallic Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for the catalytic combustion of propane: Effect of the Re addition Katarzyna Baranowska Janina Okal ⁎ Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, Okólna 2, 52-422 Wrocław, Poland Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research Polish Academy of Sciences, Okólna 2 Wrocław 52-422 Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +48 71 34 350 21; fax: +48 71 34 410 29. Graphical abstract Combustion of propane over Ru/γ-Al2O3 and bimetallic Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The combustion of propane over bimetallic Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with the Ru/Re atomic ratio of 90/10, 75/25 and 50/50 has been investigated. The catalysts were synthesized by co-impregnation method using Ru(NO)(NO3)3 and NH4ReO4 as metal precursors. Techniques such as H2-TPR, XRD, SEM, TEM, XPS and O2 adsorption were used to characterize the catalysts. All the bimetallic catalysts contained highly dispersed RuRe alloy nanoparticles (<3nm) and at Ru/Re=50/50 also Re particles (∼8nm). The catalysts with the Ru/Re atomic ratio 90/10 and 75/25 (Re loading≤3wt.%) exhibited higher activity in the propane combustion than the Ru catalyst. The improvement of the activity was related to better reducibility of the metal oxide species and higher dispersion of an active RuO x phase. The catalyst with the Ru/Re atomic ratio of 50/50 (Re loading of 9.2wt.%) exhibited lower activity because the ruthenium phase was partly blocked by inactive ReO x species. The addition of Re significantly suppressed Ru particle sintering in the Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. This causes that deactivation of the bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts under O2-rich reaction conditions was significantly lower than that of the monometallic Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Keywords Catalytic combustion Propane Bimetallic Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalyst Effect of rhenium 1 Introduction Catalytic combustion has been widely used for the abatement of dilute volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and short chain alkanes are recognized as the most difficult to oxidize among various VOCs [1]. The difficulty in destroying light alkanes, including propane, by catalytic combustion (difficult activation) makes them excellent model compounds used to test the efficiency of catalysts for total oxidation of VOCs [2]. It has been accepted that the best catalysts for the combustion of propane are based on Pt [3,4] and Pd [2]. Application of Ru-based catalysts used in the alkanes/alkenes combustion is limited. Propane, toluene and orthoxylene oxidation over Ru/CeO2 [5] and Ru/γ-Al2O3 was studied [6], butane and ethyl acetate oxidation over Ru supported on γ-Al2O3 and SnO2 was investigated [7,8]. Recently, we have shown that activity of ruthenium in the butane and propane oxidation decreased during a few successive catalytic runs or after treatment in oxygen at temperature above 250°C [7,9]. The literature data also confirmed activity loss of the Ru catalysts during VOCs combustion [8]. It has been proposed that the deactivation is due to nanoparticle sintering or to the formation of bulk RuO2 oxide that possesses lower activity than that of dispersed RuO x species [7,9]. The activity of supported metal catalysts may be modified by presence of another active component. Modifiers are usually added to promote catalytic activity and enhance resistance to deactivation. At present, a lot of research on bimetallic catalysts used in the VOCs combustion concerns mainly Pt and Pd, and more recently Au [10–12]. Over the last few years, some studies have also been focused on the catalysts with combination of a noble metal and a base metal oxides for VOCs oxidation reactions. For example, tungsten [13], vanadium [2,14] and niobium [15] oxides have been used and they are known to promote the activity of metal catalysts (Pd, Pt) for VOCs oxidation. It has been accepted that the positive promoting role of various modifiers for oxidation of alkanes, is generally attributed to a range of different factors, such as controlling the noble metal particle size, catalyst reducibility and metal oxidation state [16]. Very little interest has been focused on bimetallic Ru-based catalysts used for VOCs oxidation. Sreethawong et al. [17] found a positive effect of gold on activity of Ru/SiO2 catalysts in the oxidation of methanol. In this work, we report the first data on activity of Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts in the propane oxidation. Generally, rhenium is an important alloying agent in numerous catalytic materials, as well as in superalloys for high-temperature applications. Rhenium as a promoter is a particularly interesting metal as it is strongly oxophilic and its chemistry is expected to be dominated by its propensity to form strong metal–oxygen bonds. Also, the unique properties of rhenium oxide catalysts, due to a variety of acidic and redox properties, make them a suitable material in oxidation reactions. Catalytic activity of Ru-Re catalysts was studied only in the conversion of glycerol to propanediols (hydrogenolysis reaction) [18] or hydrogenation of amides [19], and a remarkable promoting effect of Re on activity of Ru catalysts was found. Recently, we have studied the effect of rhenium on ruthenium dispersion in the Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts [20]. It was found that in the chlorine-free bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts, dispersion of ruthenium increased with the rise of the Re loading. In this study, the same catalysts were used for the combustion of propane in order to establish the effect of rhenium on activity and stability of the Ru phase. Before testing under O2-rich reaction conditions, structure characterization of the oxidized bimetallic Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was accomplished by H2-TPR, XRD, SEM, TEM, XPS spectroscopy and O2 adsorption in order to correlate their catalytic performance with their physiochemical properties. To our knowledge, no structure characterization of the Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts subjected to the oxidation treatment is available in the literature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation and treatment of the catalysts Details of the monometallic (Re, Ru) and bimetallic Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts preparation procedure are given in [20]. The catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation or co-impregnation of γ-Al2O3 (Puralox, BET surface area of 178m2/g, pore volume 0.50cm3/g and mean pore diameter 7.8nm) with an aqueous solution of Ru(NO)(NO3)3 and NH4ReO4 (all Alfa Aesar). Next, the samples were dried in air at 110°C for 20h and reduced in H2 flow at 500°C for 4h. The catalysts were then heated in static air at 150, 200 and 250°C for 1h in order to the partly or completely oxidize metal phase. Selected reduced samples were also heated in air at higher temperature. 2.2 Structure characterization of the catalysts TEM images and SAED patterns of the oxidized catalysts were recorded with Philips CM20 SuperTwin microscope, which at 200kV provides 0.25nm resolution. The chemical composition of the catalysts after catalytic tests was determined with FE-SEM microscope (FEI NovaNano SEM 230) equipped with EDS analyzer (EDAX Genesis XM4). X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected using a PANanalytical X’Pert Pro X-ray diffractometer with CuKα radiation. Oxygen adsorption measurements, at the oxygen pressure of 80–220Torr, were performed in a conventional volumetric glass apparatus according to the procedures described in Refs. [6,21]. First, the total oxygen uptake at room temperature (RT) was determined. Next, the sample was heated to 150°C or 250°C, kept at isothermal conditions for 1h, and then cooled to RT and the total O2 uptake was measured. Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) of the oxidized catalysts was carried out in a Micrometrics Pulse Chemisorb 2705 apparatus. The sample (50mg) was first flushed with argon at 200°C for 3h and then cooled to RT. The H2-TPR profile was obtained by heating the sample under a 5% H2/Ar flow (30cm3/min) from RT to 800°C at a rate of 5°C/min. XPS experiments were carried out using a SPECS PHOIBOS 100 hemispherical spectrometer, equipped with an MgKα source (1253.6eV) operating at 250W. The spectra were processed and fitted by SPECLAB software using Gaussian–Lorentzian curve profile and Shirley baseline. The powder samples were analyzed after mounting them on a double-sided adhesive tape. Since the C 1s signal is superimposed with the Ru 3d signal, the BE of Al 2p for γ-Al2O3 as a support at 74.09eV was taken as a primary reference for all the spectra. Additionally, BE of the 1s peak of carbon contamination at 284.8eV was applied as a secondary reference. The BE values of Al 2p and C 1s were obtained from the XPS analysis of bare γ-Al2O3 heated in air at 550°C. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements The catalysts were tested in the combustion of propane using a fixed bed laboratory micro-reactor [6]. First, the catalyst (100mg) was brought into a contact for 30min at RT with the feed gas containing 5000vppm propane in air with a flow rate of 100mlmin−1. Next, the catalyst was activated in the gas mixture from RT to 150°C (the heating rate of 2°C/min) and stabilized at this temperature for 1h. Then, the temperature was lowered to 120°C and measurements were performed as the samples were heated stepwise usually in the temperature range of 120–260°C. The analyses were made at each temperature until steady-state activity was obtained, and at least two analyses were accomplished and the data averaged. The products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Perkin-ElmerARNEL Clarus 500) equipped with thermal conductivity and flame ionization detectors. The kinetic data were obtained under differential reaction conditions by decreasing the amount of catalysts to achieve less than 10–15% propane conversion. CO2 and H2O were the only detectable products indicating that propane was completely oxidized during the progress of the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure characterization of the reduced catalysts The Ru loading in all the catalysts was 5wt.%, while the Re loading amounted to 1, 3 or 9.2wt.% which corresponds to the Ru/Re atomic ratio of 90/10, 75/25 and 50/50, respectively. The Ru dispersion (H/Ru) in the monometallic Ru catalyst was determined to be 0.52 which corresponds to the Ru particle size of 1.6nm. In the bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts, the Ru dispersion increased with the Re loading and at the Ru/Re atomic ratio of 50/50 attained the maximum value of 0.83. For the Ru catalyst the average particle size of metal particles evaluated by HRTEM was 1.4nm, while for the bimetallic catalysts with composition Ru90-Re10, Ru75-Re25 and Ru50-Re50 amounted to 1.3nm, 1.1nm and 0.9nm, respectively. The morphological characteristics of the examined catalysts were given in previous work [20] and in the Supplementary material (Table S1). 3.2 Structure characterization of the catalysts after treatment in oxidative atmosphere 3.2.1 Adsorption of oxygen Table 1 summarizes oxygen adsorption data for all the studied catalysts. Small amounts of O2 were adsorbed on the Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts at RT and they correspond to dissociative chemisorption. An increase of the adsorption temperature to 150°C led to an increase in O2 uptakes indicating a reaction of subsurface Re with oxygen. However, even at 250°C the O2 uptakes are lower than that needed for total oxidation of Re to Re2O7. For the supported Re catalysts the complete oxidation of rhenium occurs at or above 300°C [21]. It has been generally accepted that rhenium oxide exists on γ-alumina surface as monomeric ReO4 species [21–24] and that the maximum capacity of this support to retain molecularly dispersed rhenium corresponds to 2.3 Re atoms/nm2 [22]. In our case, for all Re-containing catalysts, the surface Re density (0.18–1.9 Re atoms/nm2) is below the monolayer coverage (see Table S1). The oxygen adsorption data for the Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalyst show that about 90% of Ru was oxidized to RuO2 already at RT. In the samples oxidized at 150–250°C, the O2 uptakes were slightly higher than the theoretical values expected for the total oxidation of Ru to RuO2. This result may suggest the formation of a small amount of RuO4, although some literature data revealed that additional oxygen adsorption also occurred on the surface of RuO2 particles [25,26]. The O2 uptakes on the Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are usually higher at given temperature than that on the Ru sample and they increase with the Re loading (Table 1). Only for the Ru50-Re50 catalyst, the O2 adsorption at RT is 16% lower than that of the Ru catalyst which suggests a smaller extent of the subsurface ruthenium oxidation probably because of the larger covering of the RuRe nanoparticles with ReO x species. Literature data also show that in the Pt-Re/SiO2 [27], Rh-Re/SiO2 [28] and Ir-Re/SiO2 [29] catalysts Pt, Rh or Ir metal surface was partially covered by the two-dimensional Re oxide clusters. At adsorption temperature of 150°C, the complete oxidation of the metal phase in the Ru90-Re10 and Ru75-Re25 catalysts occurs, while in the Ru50-Re50 sample full oxidation is not attained even at 250°C. Since in this catalyst some fraction of Re is segregated [20], thus at 250°C spreading of the rhenium oxide species from the Re metal particles both on the Ru phase and the γ-alumina surface occurs causing additional covering of the Ru surface with ReO x species, thus hindering O2 adsorption. 3.2.2 XPS studies The characterization of the Ru-Re catalysts by this technique is very complicated because there is an overlap between the Ru 3d3/2 peak and the C 1s peak at ca. 284.8eV, the latter is due to surface carbonaceous contamination and also between the Re 4f peak (major peak) and the Ru 4p peak (minor peak). For XPS studies we chose the Ru75-Re25 catalyst which was selected as a representative material. Before the analysis, to reduce the carbon contamination concentration, the surface was cleaned for 1min by Ar+ sputtering with moderately low beam energy (2keV, 3.5μA/cm2) to avoid reduction of the metal oxide species. Fig. 1 shows XPS high resolution spectra of Ru 3d and Re 4f regions from the Ru75-Re25 catalyst reduced at 500°C and exposed to air at RT for a short time (traces a) and next oxidized in air at 150°C (traces b) and 250°C (traces c). The C 1s peak is not shown in these spectra to make the presentation clearer, although the contribution from C 1s at 284.8eV was taken into account in the spectral analysis. The Ru 3d spectra are asymmetrical and could be decomposed into three or two components. The XPS spectrum of the reduced catalyst (Fig. 1A, trace a) exhibits peaks at 279.32eV and 283.49eV, they are characteristic for metallic ruthenium [6], and also more intense peaks at 280.1 and 284.27eV, which are assigned to the Ru 3d5/2 and Ru 3d3/2 spin–orbit components of the Ru4+ species, as well as additional weaker peaks at 282.20 and 286.37eV. These peaks have been identified in the literature as a characteristic satellite feature in RuO2 probably due to unscreened final state effect [6,30]. Treatment at 150°C caused a large increase of the Ru 3d5/2 peak intensity at 280.2eV (Fig. 1A, trace b) but after treatment at 250°C the intensity of this peak did not change (Fig. 1A, trace c). The Re 4f spectrum of the Ru75-Re25 catalyst exposed to air at RT (Fig. 1B, trace a) could be decomposed into four components. The deconvoluted peaks at 40.5, 42.9, 44.8 and 46.3eV were assigned to Re 4f7/2 lines and they confirmed the existence of Reo, Re4+, Re6+ and Re7+ species, respectively [24]. The Ru 4p3/2 component at binding energy of 43.1eV [19] ascribed to metallic Ru was not taken into account in the fitting procedure since it is rather small to be meaningful. Treatment at 150°C did not cause a large change in the XPS spectrum (Fig. 1B, trace b). After oxidation at 250°C, Re4+, Re6+ and Re7+ species are present on the surface of this catalyst (Fig. 1B, trace c). Table 2 summarizes curve-fitting results obtained for the Ru75-Re25 catalyst. The distribution of oxidation states of Ru and Re ions was calculated on the basis of the most intense Ru 3d5/2 and Re 4f7/2 component of each doublet, respectively. The relative accuracy of such a quantitative analysis is about 20% [24]. In the Ru75-Re25 catalyst exposed to air at RT, only 31% of ruthenium and 11% of rhenium remains in the metallic state. At 150°C, ruthenium is completely oxidized to Ru4+. Re metal is more resistive to total oxidation, which is in agreement with the O2 adsorption data (Table 1). The XPS-determined Ru/Re atomic ratios are slightly lower than the bulk atomic ratio, (Ru/Re)bulk =3, calculated from the overall chemical composition of this catalyst. In the sample exposed to air at RT, the Ru/Al atomic ratio is 45% higher than the bulk atomic ratio (Ru/Albulk =0.027), but the Re/Al atomic ratio is even 100% higher than the bulk atomic ratio (Re/Albulk =0.009) indicating that both metals are highly dispersed and located at the outer surface of the support. Treatment at 150°C causes further growth of the Re/Al atomic ratio and then it remains constant after oxidation at 250°C. Also, the XPS-determined Ru/Al atomic ratio increases with temperature. Thus, the XPS data evidenced that oxidized Ru and Re species form a well-dispersed surface phase. 3.2.3 X-ray diffraction studies The XRD patterns of the oxidized catalysts are presented in Fig. 2 . The influence of the oxidation temperature on the phase composition of the catalysts is also shown in Table 3 . The XRD patterns of the Ru, Ru90-Re10 and Ru75-Re25 catalysts oxidized at 150°C (Fig. 2A) are similar to those of the reduced samples (Supplementary material, Fig. S1) and only contain peaks from the γ-Al2O3 indicating that metal species are highly dispersed. The pattern of the Ru50-Re50 catalyst (Fig. 2A, pattern d) contains peaks ascribed to metallic rhenium (JCPDS 71-6589). The intensity and width of the main Re(101) peak slightly changed as compared to that of in the reduced sample and calculated mean crystallite size of Re increases from 8nm to 12nm, possibly due to the complete oxidation of the smallest Re particles. The intensity of the Re(101) peak gradually decreases with temperature but the trend of the growth of the Re particles size is still maintained (Fig. 2B, Table 3). At 250°C, the Re(101) peak is very weak suggesting that the Re phase transforms into a highly dispersed phase [21,24]. XRD patterns of the samples oxidized at 200 and 250°C (Fig. 2B, C) show new reflections at 2θ =28.09°, 35.11° and 54.38° that are characteristic for RuO2 oxide. Thus, segregation process in the Ru-Re catalysts is visible at T ≥200°C. The mean crystallite size of RuO2 for the monometallic Ru and bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts with the Ru/Re atomic ratio ≤75/25, increases from 5–6nm at 200°C to about 7nm at 250°C (Table 3). For the Ru50-Re50 catalyst the temperature of 250°C is necessary for RuO2 agglomeration (Fig. 2C, pattern d). 3.2.4 TEM studies Fig. 3 shows representative TEM images and a SAED pattern (as inset) of the bimetallic Ru90-Re10 catalyst oxidized at 150°C, 200°C and 250°C. TEM images of the oxidized Ru50-Re50 catalysts are shown in the Supplementary material (Fig. S2). The morphology of the oxidized Ru catalyst (images not shown) was similar to that of the Ru90-Re10 sample (with 1wt.% of Re). The catalysts oxidized at 150°C (Fig. 3A and Fig. S2) contain a large number of small particles with size usually below 2nm. These poorly organized particles are nearly fully oxidized (Tables 1 and 2), but their identification cannot be done by HRTEM or SAED. The morphology of these catalysts was similar to that before oxidation treatment [20]. In the TEM image of the Ru50-Re50 sample oxidized at 150°C some individual Re particles were also present (Fig. S2). In the HRTEM images of Ru90-Re10 catalyst oxidized at 200°C and 250°C (Fig. 3, images B and C) we could find few small particles with lattice fringes of distances 0.32nm that well correspond to the (110) lattice plane of RuO2 oxide. The SAED pattern confirms formation of this oxide. However, the majority of the metal particles oxidized at 200–250°C are so small that they are hardly observable in HRTEM images. In the Ru50-Re50 catalyst oxidized at 200°C one ∼6nm Re metal crystallite and very large number of very small particles (∼1nm and smaller) uniformly distributed on γ-alumina were visible (Fig. S2). At 250°C, no metallic Re could be detected by TEM or SAED. Moreover, at this temperature only sparse RuO2 particles with size up to 8nm were visible. The SAED pattern also evidenced formation of RuO2 oxide. Therefore, the dominant XRD pattern of this sample (Fig. 2C, pattern d), interpreted in terms of 9nm RuO2 particles, masked the smaller homogeneously mixed particles of Ru and Re revealed by far more sensitive HRTEM technique. TEM studies fully confirm the XRD results that temperature of 250°C is needed to observe some agglomeration of the ruthenium phase in the Ru50-Re50 catalyst. Probably, the presence of large concentration of the two-dimensional Re oxide species on the Ru50-Re50 catalyst surface prevent the oxidized Ru particles from aggregation. 3.2.5 Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) Fig. 4 shows H2-TPR profiles of the oxidized monometallic (Ru, Re) and bimetallic Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The TPR profile of the Ru catalyst contains a large broad peak with maximum at 201°C and with shoulders at lower (177°C) and higher temperature (210°C) and a weak broad feature centered at 360°C (Fig. 4A, pattern a). The low temperature maxima are assigned to the reduction of RuO2 oxide in the well-dispersed and crystalline form, respectively [32], while the high temperature maximum results from reduction of the ruthenium species in the strong interaction with alumina. The reduction of Re oxide species in Re catalysts occurred at higher temperature (Fig. 4A, patterns b–d). TPR analysis of the 1% Re catalyst revealed a weak broad feature centered at 421°C. The temperature of the main reduction peak decreased to 387°C for the 3% Re catalyst and to 381°C for the 9.2% Re catalyst. Furthermore, we could distinguish two smaller peaks at 400 and 419°C for the 9.2% Re catalyst (Fig. 4A, pattern d) which suggests that different Re7+ species could be present in that sample [33,34]. Hydrogen consumption measurements indicate nearly complete reduction of the Re7+ species into metallic Reo for the 3% and 9.2% Re catalysts, while only 79% for the 1% Re catalyst. The TPR profile of the bimetallic Ru90-Re10 catalyst (Fig. 4B, pattern a) contains four peaks similar to those of the Ru catalyst. However, the metal oxide species on the Ru90-Re10 catalyst are more easily reduced. The peaks at 160–193°C can be assigned to reduction of the Ru oxide species and the weak broad feature centered at 355°C may be due to reduction both Re or Ru oxide species. The addition of larger amounts of Re resulted in the formation of one large peak centered at 193°C and 202°C for the Ru75-Re25 and Ru50-Re50 catalysts, respectively. Small broad peaks at higher temperature (at 303°C or 265°C, respectively) can be assigned to the reduction of the Re species in the stronger interaction with the support. These large low temperature reduction peaks should correspond to the co-reduction of the Ru and Re oxide species. The promotion of rhenium reduction in the bimetallic catalysts may be interpreted by hydrogen spillover from proceedingly reduced Ru to Re species. Amada et al. [35] also found that metal oxide species on the bimetallic Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst were much more easily reduced than on Ir/SiO2 and ReO x /SiO2 catalysts, which was explained by the interaction between trioxo Re species and the IrO2 phase. 3.3 Catalytic activity of the bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts Prior to catalytic tests the reduced catalysts were heated under propane/air mixture at 150°C for 1h. TEM studies showed that the overall morphology of such treated samples (images not shown) was very similar to that of the catalysts treated only in air at 150°C. XRD data confirmed TEM results, indicating that oxidized Ru species were highly dispersed. Fig. 5 shows propane conversion as a function of reaction temperature over the 5% Ru/γ-Al2O3, 3% Re/γ-Al2O3 and Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Over the Ru catalyst the oxidation of propane started at ca. 130°C followed by the steep increase in conversion up to nearly 100% at 210°C (Fig. 5A, first test), while over the Re catalyst it started at 300°C and 10% of propane conversion was achieved at temperature of 380°C. Thus, the activity of rhenium for the combustion of propane is low although the Re oxide catalysts are very active in the selective oxidation of methanol [36] or benzene [37]. Over the bimetallic Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts the conversion of propane depends strongly on the composition of the sample (Fig. 5B) and increase of the Re loading successively shifts the propane conversion curves toward higher temperature. Also, it is evident that the Ru90-Re10 and Ru75-Re25 catalysts show much better light-off characteristics than the Ru50-Re50 catalyst. To compare the oxidation activity, we measured the values of the temperature for conversion of 10%, 50% and 95% from light-off curves and the T 10, T 50 and T 95 values are given in Table 4 . For the most active Ru90-Re10 catalyst, the light-off temperature was about 76°C lower (T 50 =160°C) than for the Ru50-Re50 catalyst (T 50 =236°C). Moreover, the bimetallic Ru90-Re10 and Ru75-Re25 catalysts show much better catalytic performance (T 50 =160°C or 173°C, respectively) than the monometallic Ru catalyst (T 50 =180°C). The superior catalytic performance of bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts with the Re loading up to 3wt.% is not the result of the additive effect of rhenium and ruthenium, since the Re catalyst was completely inactive in this temperature range (Fig. 5A). Differences in conversion curves in Fig. 5B should be partly attributed to the variation in the amount of the exposed ruthenium surface since the Ru dispersion was enhanced when rhenium was added to the Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (Table S1). XPS results also show spreading of the metal phase under oxidation conditions, resulting in the high dispersed Ru-Re catalysts (Table 2). Some covering of the Ru phase by inactive two-dimensional ReO x clusters is probably the best explanation of the lower activity of the Ru50-Re50 catalyst. For this catalyst a surface coverage of ReO x species corresponds to 83% of a theoretical monolayer, while for the samples with the Re loading ≤3wt.% it does not exceed 25%. After the first test, the catalyst samples were cooled down to 120°C and the second tests were carried out at the same experimental conditions (see Supplementary material, Fig. S3). The T 50 values for the bimetallic catalysts were only 10–13°C higher than in the first test, indicating a good recycling potential of these samples for the propane combustion (Table 4). Opposite, for the monometallic Ru catalyst, the T 50 value in the second test (218°C, Fig. 5A) was about 38°C higher than in the first test (180°C). Probably, during consecutive runs of the propane oxidation structure transformations of the catalysts that cause decreasing of the number of active sites were more distinct for the Ru catalyst as compared to the bimetallic Ru-Re systems. To demonstrate stability of the Ru phase in the mono- and bimetallic catalysts, we measured propane conversion as a function of time on stream at constant temperature (lower and higher). In the first case, the initial propane conversion was kept lower than 10% and the reaction was kinetically controlled. Fig. 6A shows the turnover frequencies (TOF) at 150°C for the Ru and Ru90-Re10 and Ru75-Re25 catalysts as a function of time. The TOF values were calculated after dividing the oxidation rate expressed in micromoles of propane converted on 1g of the catalyst per second ( μ mol g cat − 1 s − 1 ) by the active site concentration determined from hydrogen chemisorption results ( μ mol g cat − 1 ) [20]. The TOF values for all the catalysts remained approximately constant during 120min of reaction time, indicating that no significant catalyst deactivation takes place on stream. Fig. 6B shows propane conversion over the Ru and bimetallic Ru90-Re10 and Ru75-Re25 catalysts as a function of time on stream at temperature of 200°C (bimetallic catalysts) or at 220°C (monometallic Ru catalyst). For the Ru-Re catalysts propane conversion remained approximately constant for 25h time on stream, thereby indicating high stability of these systems under O2-rich reaction conditions. Also, very stable activity was found for the Ru50-Re50 catalyst (not shown for brevity). Stability tests were repeated three times using the same catalyst sample and the conversion data for each cycle were reproducible which indicate further that Ru-Re catalysts exhibit stable activity. For the monometallic Ru catalyst the propane conversion decreased monotonously from 93 to 87%, showing that at high temperature (220°C) some deactivation of the catalyst occurs. The more detailed catalytic results are presented in Table 4. It is evident that the bimetallic Ru90-Re10 and Ru75-Re25 catalysts show higher reaction rate (r, micromole of propane converted on 1g of the catalyst per second) than that of the Ru catalyst. Unfortunately, we could not take into account the activity of the Ru50-Re50 catalyst since it exhibits measurable conversion above 190°C (Fig. 5B). At 150°C, the most active Ru90-Re10 catalyst exhibits the reaction rate ( 4.5 μ mol C 3 H 8 g cat − 1 s − 1 ), which is three times higher than activity of the Ru catalyst ( 1.5 μ mol C 3 H 8 g cat − 1 s − 1 ). The reaction over the Ru75-Re25 catalyst rate is also higher but differences are lower. The TOF values ranged from 16.1×10−3 to 6.2×10−3 s−1 when the Re loading in the bimetallic catalysts increased from 1 to 3wt.%. Generally, the TOF values ranged following the same catalyst trend as determined from light-off curves in Fig. 5B. We suppose that enhancement of the activity of the Ru-Re catalysts containing ≤3wt.% of Re must be caused by some type of interaction between ruthenium and rhenium which influences reactivity of the ruthenium phase. Recently, similar synergy effect between tungsten (at low tungsten loadings) and palladium supported on TiO2 for oxidation of propane was reported by Taylor et al. [16]. Avila et al. [14] found that activity of the Pt/V2O5/Al2O3 in propane oxidation increased with the vanadium oxide loading. The authors reported that at 220°C the propane combustion turnover rate increases from 25(h−1) [or 6.9×10−3 (s−1)] to 65(h−1) [or 18×10−3 (s−1)] as the V2O5 loading increases from 0 to 20wt.%. Thus, the TOF value determined for the most active Pt/V2O5/Al2O3 catalyst is close to that found for the most active Ru90-Re10 catalyst (16.1×10−3 (s−1)). The authors explained the increase of the Pt oxidation activity by the interaction between the small Pt particles with the surface acid sites which were generated by addition of V2O5 to the alumina [14]. Yoshida et al. [38] suggested that the enhanced activity of such catalysts is ascribed to less oxidized Pt or Pd by interaction with the electronegative additives used (W, V, P, Mo and Nb) under the oxidizing atmosphere. Zhu et al. [4] also demonstrated that the oxidation resistance of platinum in the Pt-W/ZSM-5 catalyst is responsible for the improved catalytic activity in propane oxidation. In the present study, the metal species in the Ru and bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts (except of Ru50-Re50) were nearly completely oxidized at 150°C as revealed the O2 adsorption results (Table 1). Also, only Ru4+ was identified by XPS experiments in the Ru75-Re25 although part of rhenium at 150°C was still in the metallic state and as ReO x species (Table 2). TEM studies show that oxidized metal (Ru or RuRe) species were amorphous and highly dispersed (Table 3). Thus, below 200°C the partly oxidized RuO x species or amorphous RuO2 particles and above 200°C also RuO2 oxide crystallites, are the catalytically active phases. According to the literature data, it is believed that the Mars–van Krevelen mechanism plays a role both in the CO and VOCs oxidation on the Ru catalysts (see Supplementary material) [7,39,40]. It is reasonable to assume that propane oxidation over the bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts also proceeds via a Mars–van Krevelen (redox) mechanism. Verykios et al. [31] showed that reducibility of metal oxide catalysts is an important parameter that determines, to a large extent, their catalytic performance for VOCs oxidation. In our study, TPR data show that metal oxide species on the Ru90-Re10 and Ru75-Re25 catalysts were more easily reduced than those on the Ru catalyst (Fig. 4). Accordingly, a correlation between the catalytic activity (both per g of the catalyst per second or TOF) and the reducibility is clearly visible for these catalysts. Mitsui et al. [41] studied oxidation of ethyl acetate over CeO2-supported metal (Ru, Pt, Pd) catalysts and suggested that metal species reducible at lower temperatures should be responsible for the high activity. In fact, the reduction of ruthenium oxide on CeO2 was initiated at lower temperature than in the case of the other metals, resulting in the highest activity. 3.4 Structure characterization of used catalysts We conducted characterization studies of catalyst samples after the second test by using EDX, XRD and TEM. The obtained characterization results represent the real structure of the working catalysts under used oxygen-rich reaction conditions. EDX results (not shown) confirmed that composition and the Ru/Re ratios in the used bimetallic catalysts were close to those in the fresh samples, indicating that no noticeable loss of Ru and Re (as volatile RuO4 or Re2O7 oxides, respectively) occurred during the course of the reaction. However, the catalyst samples went through some structural changes. All the catalysts, which were in O2-rich conditions for about 40h, exhibited the XRD patterns with the diffraction peaks of the RuO2 phase (Fig. 7 ). Reflections from this oxide are far more intensive and narrow for the Ru catalyst as compared to the Ru-Re catalysts. Additionally, in the bimetallic catalysts diffraction peaks of RuO2 oxide become weaker and broader with change of the Ru/Re atomic ratio from 90/10 to 50/50 suggesting that aggregation of the ruthenium phase depends on the Re loading. For the used Ru catalyst the mean crystallite size of RuO2 amounts to 25nm, while for the used Ru90-Re10, Ru75-Re25 and Ru50-Re50 catalysts it decreases from 10 to 7nm and even to 5nm, respectively. Interestingly, in the used bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts the mean size of the RuO2 crystallites was close to that after air treatment at 250°C for only 1h (Table 3). XRD data clearly show that deactivation of the bimetallic catalysts due to nanoparticles sintering is much lower as compared to the Ru catalyst. Fig. 8 shows the TEM images as well as the SAED pattern (as inset) of the used Ru catalyst (A) and Ru-Re catalysts with the Ru/Re ratio of 75/25 (B) and 50/50 (C). In the Ru catalyst the formation of large, irregular particles (probably aggregates) with size up to 60–80nm, and nearly complete disappearance of small particles was observed (Fig. 8A). The SAED pattern (inset in Fig. 8A) revealed the presence of RuO2 particles. For the used bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts such large aggregates of RuO2 particles were never formed. TEM image of the used Ru75-Re25 catalyst shows that RuO2 particles have dimensions of about 8–15nm (Fig. 8B). For the used Ru50-Re50 catalyst two fraction of particles are visible, few RuO2 particles with size up to 9nm and a large number of small poorly organized particles with size of 1–5nm uniformly distributed on the support (Fig. 8C). The smallest particles (∼1nm) probably contain only rhenium oxide species [21], while small particles up to 5nm probably ruthenium oxide (RuO x ) covered by ReO x species. The morphology of the used Ru50-Re50 catalyst was similar to that after oxidation at 250°C for 1h (see Supplementary material, Fig. S2). The TEM studies are in agreement with the XRD results and strongly evidence that addition of Re to Ru/γ-Al2O3 causes suppression of the Ru phase sintering during the propane combustion reaction. Concluding, the results of this study clearly evidence that ruthenium phase is stabilized in the bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts both under air atmosphere and under propane/air reaction conditions. On the basis of XPS studies, we suppose that better structural stability of the Ru-Re catalysts is associated with the segregation of rhenium at elevated temperature and under oxidizing conditions. This process leads to the formation of ReO x species on the surface of the ruthenium phase and/or on the surface of alumina support (as monomeric ReO4 species strongly interacting with the support), thus preventing the Ru particles from aggregation. At high Re loading, ReO x species may also form a shell around a Ru (or Ru-rich) core, effectively blocking the Ru phase from access to the gas phase (air), and thus blocking the formation of bulk RuO2 oxide with large particle diameter. The observed decline in the activity of the Ru50-Re50 catalyst (Table 4) is consistent with this supposition since the large amount of rhenium species covering the ruthenium surface decreased the number of active sites for the propane combustion. Our results indicate that a small concentration of Re on the surface of the Ru-Re catalysts (surface coverage of ReO x species ≤25%) was sufficient to disrupt the process that leads to the formation of large RuO2 crystals. It is also possible that partially reduced rhenium species (Re x+, where 0< x >7) can be formed on the contact of the Re oxide species with propane and these species may also influence the activity of the bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts. Moreover, some literature data revealed that ReO x clusters can play an important role in the activation of O2 to produce oxidizing species in the case of Pt-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst [27]. We also suppose that small RuO2 particles may be modified by interaction with rhenium oxide species leading to changes in the electronic properties of ruthenium. These electronically modified small RuO2 particles would contribute to the improved activity and structural stability of the bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts. 4 Conclusion A series of bimetallic Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was prepared and tested in the propane combustion for the first time. The addition of rhenium up to 3wt.% improved the catalytic activity. At the higher Re loading (Ru/Re atomic ratio of 50/50) a decline of activity caused by blocking of the ruthenium phase by ReO x species was observed. Improvement of activity was explained by higher dispersion of the active RuO x phase and better reducibility of the oxidized metal species in the bimetallic samples. The most important result of this study is that deactivation of the bimetallic Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts at oxidative conditions was significantly suppressed with respect to the monometallic Ru catalyst. The part of Re is strongly bonded to the alumina surface as ReO4 species which may block the migration of the oxidized RuO x species over the catalyst surface causing that formation of extremely large RuO2 agglomerates/particles was prevented. coredata.dc:description: The combustion of propane over bimetallic Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with the Ru/Re atomic ratio of 90/10, 75/25 and 50/50 has been investigated. The catalysts were synthesized by co-impregnation method using Ru(NO)(NO3)3 and NH4ReO4 as metal precursors. Techniques such as H2-TPR, XRD, SEM, TEM, XPS and O2 adsorption were used to characterize the catalysts. All the bimetallic catalysts contained highly dispersed RuRe alloy nanoparticles (<3nm) and at Ru/Re=50/50 also Re particles (∼8nm). The catalysts with the Ru/Re atomic ratio 90/10 and 75/25 (Re loading≤3wt.%) exhibited higher activity in the propane combustion than the Ru catalyst. The improvement of the activity was related to better reducibility of the metal oxide species and higher dispersion of an active RuO x phase. The catalyst with the Ru/Re atomic ratio of 50/50 (Re loading of 9.2wt.%) exhibited lower activity because the ruthenium phase was partly blocked by inactive ReO x species. The addition of Re significantly suppressed Ru particle sintering in the Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. This causes that deactivation of the bimetallic Ru-Re catalysts under O2-rich reaction conditions was significantly lower than that of the monometallic Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Bimetallic Ru-Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for the catalytic combustion of propane: Effect of the Re addition
